question.title: java process halts for infinite time and cannot exit properly?

node.contents: Please post a [SSCCE](http://sscce.org/) example if you want any real help

astNode.text: Please post a [SSCCE](http://sscce.org/) example if you want any real help

node.contents: I suspect your threads are in a pool which has not been shutdown. I suggest you look at the other threads to determine why that might be the case, perhaps you have a deadlock.

astNode.text: I suspect your threads are in a pool which has not been shutdown. I suggest you look at the other threads to determine why that might be the case, perhaps you have a deadlock.

node.contents: Are you able to give us a preview (preferably from pastebin, of your class that has the `Threadpool` and the `Worker` class?) .. so we get an idea of how things are initialized and constructed?

node.contents: i have java process that sends emails for different email address and i am using java thread pool executor, each thread try to send e-mail and then exits

astNode.text: i have java process that sends emails for different email address and i am using java thread pool executor, each thread try to send e-mail and then exits

node.contents: the problem is all the threads are going to wait state and can never come back to running state even the threads have completed their working successfully,

astNode.text: the problem is all the threads are going to wait state and can never come back to running state even the threads have completed their working successfully,

node.contents: queue size = 100 thread count = 5 max thread count = 10 keep alive time = 1 min

node.contents: the NotificationSender just send the email and all code is in try catch and its very simple, and even when the run method is empty the thread is not terminated

node.contents: If you look at your thread dump, the threads are waiting on the task queue for more tasks. I.e this is the expected behavior.

astNode.text: If you look at your thread dump, the threads are waiting on the task queue for more tasks. I.e this is the expected behavior.

node.contents: The JVM exits only when all non-daemon threads have terminated, and thread pool uses non daemon threads.

astNode.text: The JVM exits only when all non-daemon threads have terminated, and thread pool uses non daemon threads.

node.contents: You should call the shutdown() method on the Thread Pool to shut it down. You can call this method immediately after submitting tasks, as the already submitted task will be processed before shutting down (unlike the shutdownNow method).

astNode.text: You should call the shutdown() method on the Thread Pool to shut it down. You can call this method immediately after submitting tasks, as the already submitted task will be processed before shutting down (unlike the shutdownNow method).

node.contents: Alternatively, it is also possible to have a thread pool that uses daemon threads. These will automatically shutdown when the last non daemon thread exits.

astNode.text: Alternatively, it is also possible to have a thread pool that uses daemon threads. These will automatically shutdown when the last non daemon thread exits.

node.contents: But in your case, you want I use the shutdown method. You can also call the awaitTermination method after calling shutdown to wait for your tasks to finish, in order to print a log message etc.

astNode.text: But in your case, you want I use the shutdown method. You can also call the awaitTermination method after calling shutdown to wait for your tasks to finish, in order to print a log message etc.
